title: 10 Fuel Cell Stocks Solving the AI Energy Crisis

transcript.text:
Solving the AI energy crisis with nuclear 
energy is taking a while. And in the meantime,

data centers are scrambling to find energy 
sources. One answer could be fuel cells,

a technology that checks all the boxes and more. 
Modular fuel cell systems can be deployed in less

than a year. They're 10 to 30% more efficient than 
gas turbines, and they emit fewer emissions as

well. They're also quieter, and they come with 
more load versatility. But that doesn't mean I

should immediately go out and start adding fuel 
cell stocks to my portfolio. Not all fuel cell

stocks are created equal. We've been covering 
the fuel cell thesis for over a decade now. And

if fuel cells were ever going to have their big 
moment, it's now. Today, we're going to do three

things. We're going to check for fuel cell ETFs. 
We're then going to identify a universe of fuel

cell stocks. And we're going to identify companies 
that we might want to dig further into. So,

let's get my Lambo journey started and jump 
right into a list of stonks we can choose from.

About 5 years ago, we published a guide to 
investing in fuel cell stocks and identified

10 names of interest. Today, our tech stock 
catalog holds eight fuel cell stocks and one

fuel cell ETF, the Global X Hydrogen ETF. So, 
let's start there. It trades under the ticker

HYDR. It has less than $100 million in assets 
under management. So that means that not a lot

of investors are interested in the fuel cell 
thesis right now. It has an expense ratio of

50 BIPS. Seems about right for an actively managed 
ETF and just 25 constituents. So it's going to be

very concentrated. What we've done here is pulled 
up a list of the top 10 constituents that account

for about 70% of the entire ETF. And what we can 
then do is cross-check that list against our own

list. And here I've pulled it up. You see I've 
excluded two names here that don't have revenues.

So our rule, probably one of the most effective 
rules we have for taking out the trash is simply

this: No meaningful revenues, no interest, no 
exceptions. That's a showstopper. We don't go

any further. So, of the remaining names, six are 
overlapping with the top 10 on the Global X list,

which means there are some names we're missing. 
However, we have covered some of these missing

names. And I'll tell you one thing that's great 
about our growing community of global investors is

the network effect. So, the more people that begin 
subscribing to our channel, our premium content,

and following our brand, the more information gets 
fed to us. And a longtime reader of ours who lives

somewhere in the Nordic region, brought up a few 
names. This was nearly 5 years ago, names he said

we ought to look at. Power Cell Sweden and also 
this Nel Hydrogen from Norway. We'll take a look

at those trying to answer two basic questions. 
First of all, are they growing revenues? Right?

You can't be disrupting anything if you're not 
growing revenues. And are they being hyped? So,

starting with Power Cell, what we see starting 
off would be consistent revenue growth. This

looks really nice, right? And a positive gross 
margin. Whether or not operating income turns

positive. We can figure that out later on down 
the road. So, looking at this fundamental data,

you would expect that since the company was 
raised 5 years ago that the stock price ought to

have performed quite well, right? Wrong. This is 
rather surprising. Stock price is down 86%. Now,

for whatever reason, I've seen this same 
playbook unfold for many foreign stocks

over the years. I don't know why. So, it's this 
initial extreme overvaluation of the company and

their thesis followed by a long period of time 
where presumably the share price comes back down

to reality. And what we can do here is calculate 
a price-to-sales ratio. That's a basic method of

looking at valuation. And in our case, we use 
what's called a simple valuation ratio. That's

just market cap divided by annualized revenues. 
Now, we're going to use trailing 12-month revenues

for all these calculations in this presentation 
because for most these firms, quarterly revenues

are sporadic. So, we've done that. Here you 
get a simple valuation ratio. So, basically,

price- to-sales of around five. That's around our 
catalog average. That's what you'd expect. So,

the valuation has sort of reverted to the 
mean over time. Fundamentals have improved

while share price has sunk. And when you start 
looking at what you're getting exposure to here,

projects, so that you see there, dominates their 
revenues. We don't like project-based companies,

right? We want to see other things here. Services 
and royalty fees. These are sustainable over time.

So, this is a company that's too small to be on 
our radar despite the fact that they seem to have

a growing business that relates to fuel cells. 
The other Nordic stock on our list here, NEL ASA,

they have growing revenues, $422 million market 
cap, $99 million and trailing 12 months revenues.

And that gives them a simple valuation ratio 
of around four. So, about the same as the other

stock, right? Since shares have dropped 90% over 
the past 5 years, if there was ever a time to look

at these two Nordic fuel cell stocks, it would be 
now. That's not just because these share prices

have plummeted. It's because their fundamentals 
are showing some strength. And when we try to

explain the decrease in share price value over the 
past 5 years, what we can do is pull up the Global

X Hydrogen ETF, HYDR, and we can take a look at 
what that's done. That's our benchmark. Look,

it's down 70%. Now, that explains it. So, the 
entire fuel cell thesis has been on a decline

for the last 5 years. And we may be moving into 
a different era where fuel cells are no longer a

solution looking for a problem. There's a problem 
that fuel cells can solve, potentially. And that's

the AI energy crisis. And investors seem to be 
figuring that out to a certain extent. Here you

can see volume has increased significantly. You 
see this spike in volume over the past several

months. So investors may be thinking the same 
thing as Goldman Sachs, which is that fuel cells

will be able to solve potentially a lot of the 
short-term problems with energy supply that the AI

industry is facing. So here's something that you 
really want to pay attention to. Oftentimes, these

hardware companies, especially in the green tech 
space, tend to subsidize their products to get

them off the ground. And you can only sustain this 
act for so long. So, a number of the larger fuel

cell companies out there are not worth looking 
at until they sort this problem out. The biggest

example that we've been pointing to for years as 
problematic is Plug Power. Back in 2023, we looked

at their inability to sell a product or service 
at a profit. That was the last time we looked

at them. That was all expected to change in 2023 
because of this green hydrogen they were going to

produce internally. Well, it didn't. This company 
has now been around for 26 years, and they're

always on the cusp of a positive gross margin. And 
when you look at their fundamentals, they're worse

than ever. They're not even close to approaching a 
positive gross margin. I don't know what this is,

but it's not a sustainable business. It's nothing 
we'd ever want to have anything to do with. And

it's even more surprising to see that they're not 
alone. Another company subsidizing their products,

Fuel Cell Energy, here, trading under the ticker 
FCEL. Negative gross profits across the board,

no interest at all. And not surprisingly, their 
share price is down 96% over the past five years.

No matter how hard the cheerleaders try to 
resuscitate it, they may see some temporary

stock price appreciation. But if you do what we 
do, which is focus on investing in companies,

not stocks, then you're going to see that this 
isn't something that's worth looking at until

they solve the gross margin problem. Remember, a 
declining share price doesn't equate to value when

the fundamentals are absolute [ __ ] And also, in 
this list of companies that can't seem to produce

a product or service and sell it for more than it 
costs to produce would be Ballard. There's nothing

to see here. Also, a negative gross profit 
over time. Now, when it comes to the two UK

stocks in our list, we also have ITM Power with 
a negative gross margin. Nothing to see there.

However, there are a few companies out there worth 
investigating. One would be Ceres Power Holdings.

They have an $888 million market cap. So, 
they're under our $1 billion threshold. However,

what we see here are growing revenues over 
time. So, these are in British pounds. So,

multiply, what, by 1.3 or so. And we've done that. 
We've translated British pounds into US dollars

along the bottom here. $888 million market cap, 
around $60 million in trailing 12-month revenues,

giving them an SVR of 15. So, you see, they're 
more richly priced, and there's good reason for

that. Take a look at their gross profit margins. 
Wow. Right? So, they're approaching 80%. Now, of

course, they've been a little volatile over time, 
but in looking at their investor deck, they're

claiming to have lots of upside for data centers. 
I would want to know where these strong gross

margins are coming from. So there's certainly some 
digging that could happen here for UK investors

or any investor that's looking for some exposure 
that would also give you exposure to the British

pound. So that brings us to the two Korean stocks 
that aren't in our catalog but made their way

onto the Global X ETF. First is Doosan Fuel Cell 
Company. This is a $ 1.9 billion firm with almost

$400 million in trailing 12-month revenues, an SVR 
of five, right? So you see some consistency there

across geographies in the same theme. But what's 
worth noting here is this dramatic drop in gross

profit. So this is potentially a company that you 
might want to dig into. And I think figuring out

that gross margin anomaly is going to teach you a 
lot about their business. The other Korean stock

here, Vina Tech, $327 million company, 50 million 
in revenues, SVR of six. Again, some consistency

there in valuation. But, couple things to note 
here. First of all, it's below our market cap

threshold. They do have growing revenues, but you 
see they're sort of sporadic. So, you'd want to

understand their business and pay attention to the 
increase in volatility that could be exacerbated

by Korean retail investors right now. It just 
seems to be something you observe across all these

names because of an increased interest in fuel 
cell stocks. However, that brings us to probably

the most notable name in the list, perhaps the one 
that's worth investigating in the most. That would

be Bloom Energy. And you need to be very careful 
here. This article in Fortune says it all. Bloom

Energy stock is up a 1000% in a year because 
its fuel cells are solving AI's data center

power problem. No, that's not why it's up. It's 
up because of hype. Intrinsic value doesn't change

that quickly. So, it was significantly undervalued 
before, presumably, and now it's overvalued.

At least not as bad as we had thought. So, $28 
billion company, $1.8 billion in trailing 12-month

revenues, and SVR 15. So three times that of the 
other stocks. But perhaps there's a good reason

for that. And when you look at their margins, 
that's very important. That's been a recurring

theme throughout this presentation. See how they 
started out with negative gross margins and they

moved into positive. So you would have also seen, 
I think Rocket Lab did that. And when Rocket Lab

actually started to show positive gross margins, 
that turned out to be the right time to invest in

the stock. And here you can see, lately, they're 
hitting 30% gross margins. I suppose that's pretty

good for a hardware platform. Certainly better 
than negative gross margins, right? And their

operating margin is starting to move above zero. 
So there's certainly something to look at there in

a future presentation we're going to do on Bloom 
Energy. So when you have a thesis like fuel cells,

you always want to start out with a universe of 
stocks, as we've done today. Anything below a

sustained $1 billion market cap is not on our 
radar. You might want to have your own market

cap cut-off. And negative gross margins are always 
showstoppers. We always invest in leaders. These

are usually the larger of the lot. And right now, 
our short list of all the stocks we've looked at

today seem to be Doosan, which a lot of people are 
probably not familiar with; Bloom Energy, which a

lot of people are familiar with; and Ceres, which 
might be worth a poke around for those that dabble

in smaller stocks. So, fuel cell stocks do not 
appear to be hyped. Yet. But they may be. So,

pay attention to that. And remember that hype is 
never a good reason to invest in any thesis. Now,

I know a lot of you are looking beyond 
solutions for today's energy problems

into how we solve tomorrow's energy problems, 
and that seems to be nuclear energy. Though,

you really need to be careful about the hype. 
We've got you covered in this recent piece

that looks at some nuclear stocks that many 
DGens have been buying high and selling low.

Molasses make for a great tax write off. Yes, 
yes, they do. So, give this video on investing

in nuclear stocks a watch next. Thanks so much 
for taking the time to watch this video today.
